format:
Initial Control Settings:
  • Fully Open ALL Valves
  • Voltage is set to 0V

Procedure:
  • Increasing run 1: Set the pump voltage to 1 V by adjusting the Set-Point 1 potentiometer (turn it clockwise to increase the voltage) until 1 V is displayed on the text box with volts units in system readings section. When 1 V is displayed, start the motor, allow the system to run for 30 seconds and record the value displayed on the flowrate text box in the table below. Increment the voltage by 1 V, repeat the process above, record the corresponding flow rates for run 1 until you get to 10 V.

  • Decreasing run 1: Now decrease the voltage in steps of 1 V (turn it counter-clockwise to decrease the voltage). Record the values for flow rates in run 1 column until you get to 0 V.

  • Increasing run 2: Repeat step 1.

  • Decreasing run 2: Repeat step 2.

  • Mean: Calculate the average of two runs for both directions.

  • PLOT the results to obtain the characteristic of pump supply voltage against flowrate (Mean), for both increasing and decreasing flow rates.
It is important that the changes in supply voltage are made in one direction only, either increasing or decreasing.

template:
The water level in Tank 1 has reached 185mm.
Pump 1 was turned off cannot be started before
the water level is lower than 185mm again.

Open valves to drain water of Tank 1.

format:
Initial Control Settings:
  • Valve A and B closed
  • Valve C fully opened

Procedure:
  • Increasing n1: Start the pump and stop it when liquid level reading is 10 mm. If the value exceeded 10 mm, slowly open Valve B and allow small amount of water to drain, and closed it when you reach 10 mm. At 10 mm record the sensor output current in n1 column. Repeat until liquid level reach 190 mm.

  • Decreasing n1: Now slowly open Valve B allow water to drain and close Valve B when level is 190 mm, record the sensor output value. Repeat until 0mm.

  • Increasing n2: Repeat step 1.

  • Increasing n2: Repeat step 1.

  • Average: Calculate the average of n1 and n2 for both directions.

  • PLOT the results to obtain the characteristic of liquid level against sensor output (Average), for both increasing and decreasing sensor output currents.

Initial Control Settings:
  • Valve A closed
  • Valve C and B fully opened
The actual control panel in the lab uses a potentiometer to set supply voltage for the pump. The output of the potentiometer is an integer value which is converted into the corresponding voltage by the program on the PLC. To simulate the potentiometer with its integer scale, we use a slider here in the Online-Lab. The slider provides the PLC with an integer value.

Procedure:
  • Slowly increase the slider value, try to maintain Tank 1 liquid level at 30 mm. When the level is maintained, show the Lab assistant. Record the Level, Voltage, Int Scale and Flow rate.

  • Now target 60 mm, if it is difficult, adjust valve B until 60 mm is maintained. When the level is maintained, show the Lab assistant. Record the Level, Voltage, Int Scale and Flow rate.
Experiment 4: Tuning PID by Ziegler Nichols Methods

Initial Control Settings:
  • Valve B closed
  • Valve A and C opened
  • Proportional Weighting = 1
The actual control panel in the lab uses a potentiometer to set supply voltage for the pump. The output of the potentiometer is an integer value which is converted into the corresponding voltage by the program on the PLC. To simulate the potentiometer with its integer scale, we use a slider here in the Online-Lab. The slider provides the PLC with an integer value.
Procedure:
  • Apply the method of Ziegler Nichols

<script id="clockScript1" type="text/javascript">
  var clockInterval;
    $(function () {
        if (clockInterval) return;

        //add logo
        var div1 = $('<div/>');
        var logo = new Image();

        logo.src = 'https://webapps.mandela.ac.za/design/Resources/images/logos/FullColourLogo.PNG'
        logo.height = 60;
        div1[0].style.margin = '10px auto';

        var a = $("<a/>"); //create an anchor / hyperlink
        a.attr("href", "/ui"); //set HREF to dashboard homepage
        a.append(logo); //add logo to anchor
        div1.append(a); //add anchor to div1

        //add clock
        var div2 = $('<div/>');
        var p = $('<p/>');

        div2.append(p);
        div2[0].style.margin = '5px';

        function displayTime() {
            p.text(new Date().toLocaleTimeString());
        }
        
        clockInterval = setInterval(displayTime, 1000);

        //add to toolbar when it's available
        var addToToolbarTimer;
        
        function addToToolbar() {
            var toolbar = $('.md-toolbar-tools');
            
            if(!toolbar.length) return;
            
            toolbar.append(div1);
            toolbar.append(div2);
            clearInterval(addToToolbarTimer);
        }
        addToToolbarTimer = setInterval(addToToolbar, 100);
    });
</script>
